reviews.review_text: If everyone reports this game, im sure we can all get our money back... Just stay away from it!!

bought the deluxe edition for this game and ended up refunding it before my 2 hrs was up. the issues i encountered are as follows:-  1. the launch was horrible for steam users...ps4 got it at midnight....the steam users had to wait till 12 pm the next day....also the game had a bug where alot of users COULD NOT get the game to launch.....(this was fixed by disabling ur antivirus...but seriously why do we need to do that for the game to function)  2. The aiming feels EXTREMELY sluggish with a mouse + keyboard...you can tell this game was designed for controllers in mind....but whats baffling was the lack of controller support. Actually i rellly felt this game was designed for a DS :/  3. Prone to random disconnects and a lack of a leave punishment. Played with a group of my friends and every once in awhile one of us would drop from a game.....also when people start to lose they tend to just leave..  4.Optimization is pretty bad....albeit i didn't have any real issues some of my friends did... (im running a gigabyte geforce 970)  5.Lack of any real graphics options....they are there but its limited.  6.Maps are to small and become cluster♥♥♥♥s way to quickly....strategy is non existent imo as u can run from 1 side to the other (especially with the brainer) in a matter of seconds. It takes away the tactical aspect of the game.  7.Finding a lobby is absolute horror ...Especially for ranked on PC....without a proper community this game will die (due to it being primarily multiplayer based....the single player is laughable)  8.Animations felt stiff and some commands felt weird to execute on the keyboard..(im looking at u detaching from cover and jumping)  9. Can't start a game without a full team...whiles this is a nice addition to prevent 2v1 imbalances it became quickly annoying as we barely got anyone in lobbies quickly....This made me wonder why they did not account for the lack of a playerbase (considering this game got almost no marketing ads) and add a AI bots. Bots wont exist for competitive (even thou u need to play ranked to gain exp to rank up and get new gear) but it could have worked for casual.  Overall i really wanted to like this game...being a huge fan of the umbrella hazmat team (gotta love HUNK) but this game was just to much of a mess for me to justify paying 45$ for...so refunded and hope Technomancer will be better .   Ps. out of my 2 hrs of gametime i probably got to ACTUALLY play for about 45 mins....the rest was me waiting in lobbies with people for it to full up so we can play.

As a hardcore Resident Evil fan, I really wanted to say that I could stomach the game's awful start, and support it by supporting the developers, and hopefully they'd get the game to a better state.  I, unfortunately, cannot stomach the game for very long. Being a RE fan, I've always bought and played through each and every single game loyally. Thank god this isn't an actual RE game. The game feels like a port before the game is even put onto a console.  Pros:  -Kind of pretty, if this were 2010 -Play as some of the iconic doods from Resident evil -Some cool gun and character customization  Cons:  -Gunplay feels awful  -FORCED AIM ASSIST ON PC WITH KEYBOARD AND MOUSE (WHY THE ♥♥♥♥ IS THIS A THING)  -Trading kills is worse than when BF4 beta was a thing  -Aiming is 'sticky' The moving of crosshairs feels like turning in molasses  -Everyone in the game is a mother♥♥♥♥ing meat tank, unless you get hit in the head  -Not much emphasis on character progression, which means terrible longevity  -Very small maps. I'm not exaggerating when I say you get into combat within the first 5 seconds of getting into the game.  -Zombies are underwhelming unless your 'Zombie Jammer' gets destroyed in combat, where all zombies take 3/5ths of your health in one swipe, no matter what.  -Reiterating that gun damage is awful, entire magazines to kill people in the chest.  As a diehard RE fan, I really wanted something like a squadbased shooter like this. Some solid game ideas, but all of them poorly executed.   There's another game on steam that does everything Umbrella Corps does, but way better, and only for 10 USD. I don't think I'm allowed to promote other games in reviews, but I'm simply saying that Umbrella Corps is a weak addition to the series and that your money is better spent elsewhere. Today's Review: Umbrella Corps / Biohazard Umbrella Corps  Overview: Honestly i have to admit i've understimated Capcom and i will take my hat in front of them, since they've managed to released 2 crappy unfinished products in the same year, i think not even Ubisoft or EA have come to that yet, not in the same year. Umbrella Corps is a generic fantasy of how would be a 3vs3 team deathmatch in the Resident Evil universe would be, that IF you can find anyone playing this game of course, so my recomendation for you, if you're crazy enough to actually buy this game for ANY price, is that you get ready a movie, some popcorn and a soda, then get comfty in your couch and press the button to start searching for a match, since it only have 2 modes you will think 'this guy must be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ me, that can't be that bad' ohhhhhhh yes! it is, so get a movie, put Play and enjoy the 2 hours of queue this game will give you to finish a movie before starting an online play session. Also there's a poor excuse for sp mode (pretty much like the poor excuse for SP mode in Street Fighter V) called 'The Experiment' were you will be put to the maps in MP to kill zombies, ganados, zombie dogs and some bows to collect samples or activate points or other things that never quiet fit... anywhere, i just thank Capcom they didn't called this game: 'Resident Evil: Umbrella Corps' because this is one of my favorite franchises and this... this is sad honestly, but hey it's 30 bucks and it will be on sale really really fast, here is the list of pros and cons.  Pros: (This was REALLY hard for me, like defending a serial killer in a case from a docen of murdered babies, and you're his lawyer)  *Fast Peaced action in third person while aiming in first person *Not AAA price (29.99USD price and 39.99 for the deluxe edition) *The attept of adding a SP mode that kinda work out if you just wanna kill zombies *Set within the Resident Evil world using the elements of SOME popular maps in: Code Veronica, 1 and 2, 4 and 5 (so far) *MP might be fun if you find ppl playing or you have 2 more friends  Cons: (inhales...)  *Dead on arrival, no playerbase in pc, completly dead MP *'Campaign' is 3 hours short (at best) *Either an xbox controller or the mouse is EXTREMELY bad, causing you to move or aim like if you had a 50 dpi mouse, making you to go running to the settings looking for mouse sensitivity *MP (almost) exclusive game with only 2 MODES *30 dollars price tag for a game that's unfinished, unpolished, srly lacking inspiration call-of-duty/ish clone. generic third/first fps shooter *Price tag over a game that some others do a best job by being free (such as dirty bomb) *Headshot animations on zombies take time to complete, so in most cases is best to shoot them in the body *Stuff like the heads from Resident Evil and colors for the backpack are behind a dlc *Much more PC hunger than the minimum requirements *NOT ANY FORM OF ANTI-CHEAT SYSTEM, YES IN A 2016 A AAA TITLE DEVELOPED BY CAPCOM HAVE CHEATERS RUNNING ARROUND FREE AND UNCHAINED *I will add more as i've encounter more issues with the game   Metascore: 28/100 Even worst than operation raccoon city, and we all know what a piece of turd that was.

I really wanted to like this game. I didn't give in to all the negativity surrounding its release. I pre-ordered the delux edition as soon as I could...  Well sometimes you are just dead wrong. The game is atrocious. Plenty of people have talked about a lot of problems with the game, but I'm going to talk about rediculous design flaws that never should have made it past an alpha or beta test.  - You crawl at an insanly fast speed...it may sound weird but it shouldn't be that fast, there needs to be a speed penalty.  - The cover system that you see in the cool promo videos is USELESS. NOBODY uses the cover system, because everyone runs around like coked up energizer bunnies. It's almost like they designed the cover system for a tactical shooter, but forgot everyone would just play the game like Quake. There is no advantage to being 'tactical', just run up and jam the ice pick in someones head.  - You can't bind extra mouse buttons. Have a sweet gaming mouse? Well sucks for you, because you are only going to use the left and right mouse buttons on it.  - Hitting escape in the training mode or single player challange mode doesn't pause the game. It just takes you to the menu but the game still runs behind it, and zombies WILL kill you. Really? I can't pause this game to take a ♥♥♥♥? This might sound like a minor nitpick, but if someone developes a game with these glaring issues, it really shows the lack of quality control and insultingly low amound of effort they put in.   Just a poorly designed, executed, and supported game. Oh yeah good luck finding people to play with online anyway.
So I played just under an hour, might not be the best of time to judge the game....  But I'm going to do so anyways, Just spare your money and walk away.  Don't do the same mistake I did.
Well, I'd say this game deserves a score equal to the average number of players it has.

TL:DR Enjoyed some aspects but overall felt like it didnt know what it was trying to aim for. Also the worst FOV ive ever experienced in a TPS. Going to get a refund but if it still retains a playerbase i will pick it up on a sale and would reccomend you do the same too.   Pros: + Cool Concept, 'BUT ITS NOT RESIDENT EVIL' i know its not and its not called resident evil, its a third person shooter with a resident evil skin on it + Very tactical movement/aiming system which is something i want in games like Ghost Recon where you can change the level you are at in cover to shoot from a lower or higher angle, being able to manually open a door slowly and shoot through the cracks, aiming before climbing up from a ladder. Very unique and awesome ideas that should be implemented into other games like it + A lot of customisation options   Cons: - THAT FOV IS HORRIBLE. I CANT SEE ANYTHING IN FRONT OF ME, MY TEAMMATES, MY ENEMIES, ANYTHING. Unless every Umbrella op is a pirate i cant see why you would use an FOV like this. Resident Evil 5 had a bad FOV problem but this is just terrible especially with the competitive theme they are aiming for, i cant coordinate with my team if i can only see them within 50 degrees of my right eye. - Aiming is so slow. Never before have i needed to crank sensitivity to its max and still its not enough, fair enough if you want a slow paced aiming style focusing on precision but this is a fast paced competitive shooter with rounds lasting 3 minutes in tiny maps - Melee is clunky. Return of the COD Knife lunge, ive had people charge at me, sponge bullets and then teleport to me and stick an axe in my skull - Tactical coordination is ruined. You can see everyone (not just your team and your killer) literally everyone on the map after you die: HOW IS THAT COMPETITIVE.  - Small map issues meaning i spawn behind enemies and such  Neutral viewpoints - Singleplayer feels mashed in there just to appease the people without a stable online connection or the people who cry about online only games. Glorified challenge mode but  -+ Graphics arent great but the game runs smoothly and doesnt look too bad for it -+ DLC gives the players more customisation options including well known classic characters (and Jake) but is a little pricey but a cool idea. I think it wouldve been better to include those items as part of challenges or ranking up though.  Overall its a neat idea and i liked some aspects, especially the tactical elements. But they dont really work in such a fast paced game. If this game had bigger maps and a slower pace i think i would prefer it more with the opening door mechanics and climbing ladders and even opening shutter doors and aiming while you do it. The FOV is inexcusable regardless of what you were trying to achieve, ive had enemies run into me and me run into them or get killed by people by left eye shouldve seen but i need to switch shoulders to see out of that eye. The game feels like they tried to amalgomate cool original slow paced mechanics into an incredibly fast paced competitive style game and it doesnt really work for me. Ill be getting a refund until a sale happens on it if it retains a playerbase by then anyway. Until then i cannot reccomend the game personally.

This is my last review of this game. I took down previous reviews because they were mostly written out of anger towards many of the (at times baseless) negative reviews and forum trolls. I'll try to keep it more objective, as a traditional review should be. This will simply be my honest review of the game, from the viewpoint of a long time tactical shooter fan, NOT a Resident Evil fan.  Umbrella Corps is a thinking person's shooter (think SOCOM, not CoD); you win by outsmarting your enemy, not by skill alone. There are two main gametypes; One Life Match, which is essentially single-elimination deathmatch, and Multi-Mission. Multi-Mission allows you to respawn and plays first team to win 3 rounds of constantly changing objectives (ie. Round 1 is simple TDM, Round 2 you have to find a special zombie and kill it before the other team, Round 3 etc. etc.) At first you might get away with simply running all over the map looking for kills, but the more you play the more you come to appreciate the freedom with which you have to approach your objective. Many of the walls and buildings can be scaled by the player with the use of your climbing gear, adding another level of verticality to all of the maps that ensures no two rounds play out exactly the same, even on the relatively small maps. Rather than take the staircase you know the enemy is watching, simply scale the banister and come up behind them. Rather than swing open the door that you know the enemy is waiting behind, you can fluidly open it while rifle-checking at the same time. When climbing ladders, you can make a quick sweep with your weapon before finishing the climb. The game even comes with a wheel of customizable pre-made strats to set up with your team at the beginning of each match (though whether or not your team actually follows the strategy is another story :P).  There's a fairly decent amount of primary and secondary weapons, though later unlocks simply allow different playstyles and aren't necessarily better than the weapons everyone starts out with, keeping it balanced. There is a relatively robust selection of grenades, from normal frags to smokes for advanced strategies, semtex and even grenades that disable and eventually destroy any zombie jammers in the area, leaving the enemy vulnerable to zombie attacks. Pistols are more fun to use for me in this game than in any other multiplayer third-person shooter I've played, and they are just as formiddable as any of the primary weapons in the hands of someone with good aim and quick clicking. There are NO sniper rifles; this game has a strong focus on CQB (close quarters battle) and as such the weapons featured are either PDWs (personal defense weapons, sort of like submachine guns), pistols, and shotguns. The weapons are all modeled on real world guns with (what I'm assuming are) Resident Evil universe based names. The only aspect I found lacking were the brainers. The brainer is the melee weapon every character is given that lets you run faster and get insta-kills if you can sneak up behind them, because otherwise there is a good chance you will get brainer-countered and killed. By holding right click (or right trigger) while using the brainer you can heat it up, making it impossible to be countered but completely eliminating any element of stealth by letting out a distinct powering up noise for everyone to hear and prepare for. My issue with the brainer is there are only 3 types available in the game, which is a stark contrast to the other equipment selections. They each have different characteristics, taking longer or shorter to heat up and staying heated for longer or shorter, so that may be why the selection is so small, but it would have been nice if they had added other effects as well.  The zombies roaming throughout the map actually add a tactical aspect; it isn't like Turok for the 360 where the AI was more of a nuisance than anything. You can distract the enemy team by shooting their zombie jammer and suddenly forcing them to deal with the hordes of zombies that were ignoring them before. You can grab attacking zombies and use them as a temporary shield (though they will eat you if you hold it for longer than a few seconds). They can be used as concealmeant, allowing you to blend in with the horde while your jammer is still active (for this reason, you'll find a lot of people decide it's easier to crawl everywhere so it's always good to keep your eyes both high and low), and in some gametypes they are part of the objective itself. I believe the zombie AI concept was overall executed well, if not for a lack of variety in enemy types (walkers, crawlers, dogs, birds are the 4 types you'll see in each level).   Customization was one of the biggest draws of this game to me, in all honesty. There aren't enough shooters that allow you to customize your character in my opinion, and this one gives you a good amount of options from the start. The weapon customization is also fairly deep, letting you change the paint scheme, optics, ironsights, and suppressors, and even aiming reticule of all the weapons that allow attachments. If you are like me and are a sucker for cool looking tactical ♥♥♥♥, you could probably dump a good amount of time in the customization options alone.  Now, on to the bad. This game is far from perfect. Oddly, you can't rebind certain staple FPS keys (such as CTRL) and are stuck using the spacebar to crouch/prone (though you get used to it after a while). The playerbase is nearly dead, although there is a dedicated group of around 100+ players who have created steam matchmaking groups to help find players. Even with this, it can sometimes take 30+ minutes to find one match (You may think differently, but in my opinion no one would be willing to wait that long for a maximum 12 minute match unless it was worth it). As one could expect of a game who's player base consists of a small bunch of people spread all over the world, sometimes the lag is unplayable(but not all or even most of the time). Why was this game dead on release? Well, it honestly depends on who you ask. I personally feel that if this game had be released in its own universe with zombies and special forces instead of Resident Evil's it would have done much better. Resident Evil fans and tactical shooter fans can be two completely different groups of fans. This game is a tactical shooter, dressed up as Resident Evil and marketed to Resident Evil fans; it was a recipe for disaster. However, that doesn't mean the core gameplay is bad or broken, certainly not deserving to be removed from steam. For half the price of a full-priced game, I have put more hours into this than many of the $60 multiplayer games I own (*cough* Battleborn). And I will be honest, I refunded the game when it first came out because, at the time, the lag truly was unplayable. After seeing it go through several updates, I caved and re-purchased it and have not been disappointed. They have been diligently patching it since then, and at this point most of of the game breaking bugs and issues with balance have been addressed.   tl;dr I recommend Umbrella Corps to fans of tactical shooters who want to play a game with a bit of a SOCOM-esque feel with a zombie twist. As someone who has never played or had interest a Resident Evil game, I can honestly tell you that Umbrella Corps is a different game for different people. I'm sure there are Resident Evil fans who can also enjoy a game like this, but don't buy it expecting a fully fleshed out singleplayer experience. I'm not sure how many of the negative reviews actually gave the game a chance (and how many of them were the people saying they would boycott this game from the moment it was announced, before it even came out), but I am sure that there are plenty of people who greatly enjoy this game. If it was actually broken, or bad, it would be dead and gone off steam like Breach.

Definetly Reccomend if on sale somewhere. Fun little tactical shooter, quick matches. Mouse Aiming right now is iffy but it works fine on a controller. You can get used to the Mouse controls by just turning up your mouse sensitivity. Might not be perfect but it helps if you don't happen to have a controller.  Only 2 competative game modes right now, 1 life per round team elimination and an objective mode where the objective changes every round. There are zombies/plagas infected B.O.W.s on all the maps and they can kill you very quickly, especially the dogs. It adds something else to worry about other than the enemy team some times.   It's fun, looks nice enough for me and its getting free DLC. Unlike many of the negative reviews, I have had no crashing or problems of that sort at all. You may also want to take into account how much of a Capcom/RE 'fan' the reviewer is, since the more they proclaim to love RE the more they problably hate this game or Capcom in general.  If you are looking for a quick to pick up 3 v 3 tactical shooter with Resident Evil flair this is the game 4 u gamerz.

If you go into this expecting any sort of survival horror, that's your mistake and you shouldn't bash the game for your inability to read.  NOTE: Do not buy if you don't have a controller, as mouse movement is currently garbage.  Pros: - Responsive controls (minus mouse movement) - Nice graphics for the most part - Good number of weapon options - Large number of character customization options, including patches, colors, helmets, armor pieces, and emblems - 7 different maps, playable across all gamemodes - Most of the maps are pretty large - Single player mode is a tad repetitive, but gets very challenging - Killing zombies is satisfying and responsive - Maps are faithful recreations of classic RE locations - A wealth of settings - Can host private games with friends, with no minimum number of players req. to start - Multi-mission keeps things from getting stale - 3v3 allows for teams to work together easier, given their smaller size  Cons: - Mouse movement is horrendus - No co-op or bot support, which is bad for a game that won't have a large player base - Map from RE5 visually looks quite dull in comparison to the other maps - I have not played it yet, but I've heard that the online mode is buggy for some, although this is something that could be fixed in the future. - Music has that generic CoD Mountain Dew ad dubstep music (can luckily be turned off) - Public matches appear to be Peer-to-peer? Someone in the match is always the host, and connection can be laggy if their internet sucks - Player base dying rapidly. I recommend getting some friends together or meeting people in the forums  Overall, if you like arcade-y team based shooters and like the more action side of Resident Evil, you'll probably like this game. I still find it less annoying than RE6. It's important to remember that this is a clearly low budget spin-off game, and in no way any indication of the future of the series. Also, it's max price $30 so don't expect the amount of content you'd find in a $60 game. I'd still say wait until the bugs get ironed out if you plan on playing online.
